description: From Middle English justifien, from Old French justifier, from Late Latin justificare (“make just”), from Latin justus, iustus (“just”) + ficare (“make”), from facere, equivalent to just +‎ -ify.

verbs.description: justify (third-person singular simple present justifies, present participle justifying, simple past and past participle justified)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide an acceptable explanation for.
examples: How can you justify spending so much money on clothes?
Paying too much for car insurance is not justified.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be a good, acceptable reason for; warrant.
examples: Nothing can justify your rude behaviour last night.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To arrange (text) on a page or a computer screen such that the left and right ends of all lines within paragraphs are aligned.
examples: The text will look better justified.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To absolve, and declare to be free of blame or sin.
(reflexive) To give reasons for one’s actions; to make an argument to prove that one is in the right.
examples: She felt no need to justify herself for deciding not to invite him.

entries.meaning: To prove; to ratify; to confirm.
(law) To show (a person) to have had a sufficient legal reason for an act that has been made the subject of a charge or accusation.
(law) To qualify (oneself) as a surety by taking oath to the ownership of sufficient property.
